importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The start date of the last government shutdown, which began on December 22, 2018, and lasted 35 days, making it the longest in history.
The end date of the last government shutdown, which ended on January 25, 2019, marking a 35-day shutdown and the longest in U.S. history.
The date of the latest update to the article, indicating the current government shutdown is ongoing as of October 21, 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 35-day shutdown from December 2018 to January 2019 was the longest in history and highlighted the economic and political consequences of prolonged government funding lapses.

The current government shutdown in 2025 underscores ongoing political gridlock and the failure to pass appropriations bills, resulting in a full shutdown with significant societal and economic impacts.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown (2018–2019) lasted 35 days, the longest in nearly 50 years, and cost the U.S. an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP.
The current shutdown in 2025 is a full government shutdown, as no of the 12 required appropriations bills have been passed by Congress.
The 2018 shutdown was partial, with some agencies operating and others shut down, affecting around 800,000 employees, of which 300,000 were furloughed.
In the current shutdown, federal agencies across the board are not funded, leading to halted services and impacts on public trust and economic activity.

Political polarization and narrow majorities (such as Speaker Mike Johnson’s in the House) have made it difficult for Congress to reach bipartisan agreements on spending, contributing to extended shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Gillian Roberts
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A CNN journalist who co-authored the article, contributing to reporting on the ongoing government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Kaanita Iyer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A CNN journalist who co-authored the article, contributing to reporting on the ongoing government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article, providing public information on the duration and impact of recent government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Congressional Budget Office (CBO)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provided an estimated $3 billion GDP loss from the 2018 shutdown, offering economic context to the shutdown’s impact.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Currently oversees a narrow House majority, contributing to political gridlock and making compromise difficult in funding negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Senate filibuster
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A procedural barrier that prevents the GOP from passing funding bills without 60 votes, contributing to shutdowns due to legislative gridlock.

namedEntities.name: U.S. federal government
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The entity that has been shut down, affecting millions of employees and public services, signaling a breakdown in democratic governance.

namedEntities.name: 12 appropriations bills
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The number of bills Congress has failed to pass, which is the reason for the current full government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: 800,000 employees
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The total number of federal workers affected during the 2018 shutdown, illustrating the scale of workforce disruption.

namedEntities.name: 300,000 furloughed employees
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The number of employees who were not paid and asked not to report to work during the 2018 shutdown, highlighting economic and social consequences.

namedEntities.name: partial shutdown (2018)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key distinction from the current full shutdown, showing that funding was only approved for certain agencies, not all.

namedEntities.name: full government shutdown (2025)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The current state of the federal government, where no funding has been approved for any agency, affecting all services.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. federal government is currently in a full shutdown in 2025 due to Congress failing to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. This follows a previous 35-day partial shutdown in 2018–2019, the longest in nearly 50 years, which cost the nation an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP and affected around 800,000 federal workers, with 300,000 furloughed. The article highlights the political and structural challenges contributing to these shutdowns, including partisan divisions, narrow congressional majorities, and the Senate filibuster rule, which blocks passage of spending legislation. The current shutdown, unlike the 2018 event, affects all federal operations, with no agencies operating under partial funding, underscoring a significant crisis in the functioning of U.S. governance and public service delivery.
title: The last government shutdown was the longest in nearly 50 years. Here are all the recent shutdowns in one chart
